title: How does carer quality of life vary by gender?
analysis_commentary:
In 2010, the next steps for the Carers strategy set out the aim for 'carers to be able to have a life of their own alongside their caring role'. To explore if this happening, we can look at carer-reported quality of life using the Survey of Adult Carers (for details on how this score is calculated please see 'about this data' below).

Here, a higher score represents a higher quality of life, with 12 being the maximum. In England, in 2012-13 we can see that the average score of 8.1 is well above the halfway mark of 6 and shows that there is a reasonably high quality of life among carers in that year. Males have the highest score of 8.3, which is 0.3 higher than females who score 8.0.
data_source: Health & Social Care Information Centre, Personal Social Services Survey of Adult Carers in England
